June 10: President of Ghana Joins Board of Global Center on Adaptation

R otterdam/Nairobi, 10 June 2025 - The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) today announced that His Excellency John Dramani Mahama, President of the Republic of Ghana, has joined its Board. He joins a distinguished group of global leaders - including Mia Amor Mottley, Prime Minister of Barbados; Samia Suluhu Hassan, President of Tanzania; William  Samoei Ruto, President of Kenya and Hilda Heine, President of the Marshall Islands - committed to advancing climate adaptation as an urgent development and economic priority.

June 10: GCA Supports World Bank's Landmark Facility to Catalyze Climate-Resilient Housing in Africa

N AIROBI / ROTTERDAM, 10 June 2025 - The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA), in partnership with the World Bank and the Eastern and Southern African Trade and Development Bank (TDB), has today launched GCA's technical assistance for the Africa Green, Resilient and Inclusive Housing De-Risking (GRIHD) Facility - a groundbreaking initiative that will mobilize over half a billion dollars in private capital to address the urgent housing and climate adaptation needs across Africa.

May 20: GCA Supports Climate Adaptation Measures for Southern Niger Connectivity Project

R otterdam, the Netherlands, 20 May 2025 - The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) today welcomed the World Bank's approval of a landmark US$400 million financing package for the Southern Niger Connectivity and Integration Project (PICSN), a transformative investment to improve climate-resilient infrastructure, logistics, and integration across one of the most fragile and climate-vulnerable regions in the Sahel.

May 20: GCA to Strengthen Rural Climate Resilience in Mauritania through Water Access

N ouakchott / Rotterdam, 20 May 2025 - The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) and the African Development Bank (AfDB) have announced a strategic collaboration through the Africa Adaptation Acceleration Program (AAAP) to improve water security and climate resilience for vulnerable rural communities across Mauritania.

The $20.4 million investment project, Strengthening Mauritania's Rural Resilience through the Management and Development of Water Resources (RRR-Water) will enhance sustainable water access for domestic, productive, and ecosystem purposes across the Brakna, Adrar and Tagant regions-some of the most climate-vulnerable areas in the country.

May 19: GCA Strengthens Urban Climate Resilience in Bangladesh through Training-of-Trainers Initiative

D haka, Bangladesh, 19 May 2025 - The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA), in partnership with the International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED) and the Bangladesh Institute of Planners (BIP), has completed a three-day Training-of-Trainers (ToT) to build long-term national capacity for climate-resilient urban development. Held from May 17 to 19 in Dhaka, the ToT prepared 29 trainers to deliver the GCA's Urban Climate Resilience Masterclass (UCRMC) to local government officials from urban municipalities, known as pourashavas, across Bangladesh.

October 14: GCA CEO Launches Youth Climate Adaptation Action Day at Tsinghua University

Professor Patrick Verkooijen, CEO of the Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) and Chancellor of the University of Nairobi, delivered a keynote address at Tsinghua University today, marking the official launch of Youth Climate Adaptation Action Day. His lecture, "Global Youth and the Acceleration of Climate Adaptation Action," addressed the critical role of youth-led innovation in combating the escalating climate crisis. This event was part of a larger global mobilization, with over 320 youth-led climate adaptation events taking place in 70 countries. The Youth Climate Adaptation Action Day aims to empower young people to lead climate adaptation efforts worldwide. Organized by GCA, this day serves as a platform for youth to share ideas, develop solutions, and drive community action to mitigate the impacts of climate change. "Lighthouse Events," are being held across multiple countries, including China, Bangladesh, Kenya, and the Netherlands, showcasing youth-driven adaptation strategies such as community clean-ups, reforestation, and water conservation projects.

Source: Company Website

October 07: GCA and PKSF Collaborate on Green Climate Fund Proposal to Bolster Climate Resilience in Bangladesh's Inland Aquaculture

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA), in partnership with the Palli Karma-Sahayak Foundation (PKSF), convened a high-level session with leading aquaculture experts from the Bangladesh Agricultural University (BAU) today to advance the development of a comprehensive concept note for the Green Climate Fund (GCF). This initiative aims to address the mounting climate change vulnerabilities affecting Bangladesh's inland aquaculture sector and to enhance the resilience of this vital industry.

September 30: Global Center on Adaptation: Africa Adaptation Acceleration Program Receives NDC Investment Award

N ew York, 24 September 2024 - The Africa Adaptation Acceleration Program (AAAP) has been honored as the "Best Investable NDC Adaptation Investment Initiative of the Year" at the 2024 African NDC Investment Awards. This award, presented during the African NDC Institutional Investment Summit in New York, recognizes the AAAP's groundbreaking efforts to accelerate climate adaptation across the continent.

September 20: Global Center on Adaptation: Nominees Announced for the 2024 Local Adaptation Champions Awards

T he Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) announced the 21 nominees for the 2024 Local Adaptation Champions Awards today. These prestigious awards, which spotlight groundbreaking and scalable locally led efforts, celebrate innovation in addressing the growing impacts of climate change while fostering resilience at the community level. The nominees have been selected in four categories: Water Security, Food Security, Local Entrepreneurship, and Urban Adaptation Solutions. This year the Global Center on Adaptation received a record 870 applications from organizations in 107 countries.

August 22: Global Center on Adaptation Partners with African Development Bank to Enhance Climate Resilience in Comoros' Port Infrastructure

Rotterdam, Netherlands, 22 August 2024 - The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) is collaborating with the African Development Bank (AfDB) under the African Adaptation Acceleration Program (AAAP) to support the Union of Comoros in developing and enhancing the resilience of its maritime infrastructure. The Comoros Maritime Corridor Development and Regional Trade Facilitation Project, aims to boost the country's port capacities, fostering regional trade and ensuring long-term sustainability in the face of climate change. Comoros, a Small Island Developing State (SIDS) located in the Indian Ocean, faces unique challenges due to its geographic isolation, economic constraints, and heightened vulnerability to climate hazards such as earthquakes, cyclones, floods and tsunamis. The nation's economy, heavily reliant on maritime trade, fisheries, agriculture, and tourism, needs resilient infrastructure to sustain its growth and integration into broader continental trade networks.

September 17: Global Center on Adaptation: Turning Waste into Wealth through Climate Adaptation

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) marked a significant milestone in climate adaptation, sustainable urban development, and green jobs with the inauguration of 12 Black Soldier Fly (BSF) units in Mukuru, Nairobi today. The initiative, undertaken through the Africa Adaptation Acceleration Program (AAAP) in partnership with the African Development Bank (AfDB), DanChurchAid, and local partners Akiba Mashinani Trust (AMT) and Miramar Foundation, is set to revolutionize waste management in one of Nairobi's largest informal settlements while providing employment opportunities for young people by equipping them with skills in sustainable agriculture, waste management, and business management.

September 16: Africa Partners Delivering Adaptation Results: $10 Billion of Development Investments Made Climate Resilient

Highlighting the results of the first 36 months of the world's largest climate adaptation program, the Africa Adaptation Acceleration Program (AAAP), ministers, experts and practitioners in and outside of Africa, gathered for the program's 4th Partnership Forum in Nairobi, Kenya. AAAP so far mainstreamed climate adaptation into over $10 billion of development investments in Africa from various international financial institutions (IFIs), benefiting over 63 million people across 37 African countries. urn:contentItem:6FGJ-G8R3-RRV5-P009-00000-00This election, what are Labor and the Coalition offering on the energy transition, climate adaptation and emissions?2025-04-03T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisThis election, what are Labor and the Coalition offering on the energy transition, climate adaptation and emissions?Johanna Nalau, Senior Lecturer, Climate Adaptation, Griffith University

Cost of living is trumping climate at this election, but the issue won't disappear. Here's what major parties are offering - and what we actually need.

Australia's 2022 federal election was seen as the climate election. But this time round, climate policy has so far taken a back seat as the major parties focus on cost-of-living issues.

Despite this, climate change remains an ever-present threat. Last year was the world's hottest on record and extreme weather is lashing Queensland. But there are hints of progress. Australia's emissions have begun to fall and the main power grid is now 40% renewable.

So before Australians head to the polls on May 3, it's worth closely examining the climate policies of the two major parties. What are they offering on cutting emissions, preparing for climate-boosted disasters and future-proofing our energy systems? And where are the gaps?

Energy transition - Tony Wood, Grattan Institute

Cost-of-living pressures, escalating damage from climate change and global policy uncertainty mean no election issue is more important than transforming Australia's economy to achieve net zero. But our energy supply must be reliable and affordable. What should the next government prioritise

There is great pressure to deliver power bill relief. But the next government's priority should be reducing how much a household spends on energy, rather than trying to bring down the price of electricity. Far better to give financial support for battery storage and better home insulation, to slash how much power consumers need to buy from the grid.

The Liberal-led Senate inquiry has just found supporting home electrification will also help with cost of living pressures.

The electricity rebates on offer from Labor and the temporary cut to fuel excise from the Coalition aren't enough.

Federal and state governments must maintain their support and investment in the new transmission lines necessary to support new renewable generation and storage.

Labor needs to do more to meet its 2030 target of reaching 82% renewables in the main grid. Currently, the figure is around 40%. The Coalition's plan to slow down renewables, keep coal going longer and burn more gas while pushing for a nuclear future carries alarmingly high risks on reliability, cost and environmental grounds.

Gas shortfalls are looming for Australia's southeast in the next few winters and the price of gas remains stubbornly high. Labor does not yet have a workable solution to either issue, while the Coalition has an idea - more and therefore cheaper gas - but no clarity on how its plan to keep more gas for domestic use would work in practice.

So far, we have been offered superficially appealing ideas. The field is wide open for a leader to deliver a compelling vision and credible plan for Australia's net-zero future.

Climate adaptation - Johanna Nalau, Griffith University

You would think adapting to climate change would be high on the election agenda. Southeast Queensland just weathered its first cyclone in 50 years, estimated to have caused A$1.2 billion in damage, while outback Queensland is enduring the worst flooding in 50 years.

But so far, there's little to see on adaptation.

Both major parties have committed to building a weather radar in western Queensland, following local outcry. While welcome, it's a knee-jerk response rather than good forward planning.

By 2060, damage from climate change will cost Australia $73 billion a year under a low emissions scenario, according to a Deloitte report. The next federal government should invest more in disaster preparation rather than throwing money at recovery. It's cheaper, for one thing - longer term, there are significant savings by investing in more resilient infrastructure before damage occurs.

Being prepared requires having enough public servants in disaster management to do the work. The Coalition has promised to cut 41,000 jobs from the federal public service, and has not yet said where the cuts would be made.

While in office, Labor has been developing a National Adaptation Plan to shape preparations and a National Climate Risk Assessment to gather evidence of the main climate risks for Australia and ways to adapt.

Regardless of who takes power, these will be useful roadmaps to manage extreme weather, damage to agriculture and intensified droughts, floods and fires. Making sure climate-exposed groups such as farmers get necessary assistance to weather worse disasters, and manage new risks and challenges stemming from climate change, is not a partisan issue. Such plans will help direct investment towards adaptation methods that work at scale.

New National Science Priorities are helpful too, especially the focus on new technologies able to sustainably meet Australia's food and water needs in a changing climate.

Emission reduction - Madeline Taylor, Macquarie University

Emission reduction has so far been a footnote for the major parties. In terms of the wider energy transition, both parties are expected to announce policies to encourage household battery uptake and there's a bipartisan focus on speeding up energy planning approvals.

But there is a clear divide in where the major parties' policies will lead Australia on its net-zero journey.

Labor's policies largely continue its approach in government, including bringing more clean power and storage into the grid within the Capacity Investment Scheme and building new transmission lines under the Rewiring Australia Plan.

These policies are leading to lower emissions from the power sector. Last year, total emissions fell by 0.6%. Labor's Future Made in Australia policies give incentives to produce critical minerals, green steel, and green manufacturing. Such policies should help Australia gain market share in the trade of low-carbon products.

From January 1 this year, Labor's new laws require some large companies to disclose emissions from operations. This is positive, giving investors essential data to make decisions. From their second reporting period, companies will have to disclose Scope 3 emissions as well - those from their supply chains. The laws will cover some companies where measuring emissions upstream is incredibly tricky, including agriculture. Coalition senators issued a dissenting report pointing this out. The Coalition has now vowed to scrap these rules.

The Coalition has not committed to Labor's target of cutting emissions 43% by 2030. Their flagship plan to go nuclear will likely mean pushing out emissions reduction goals given the likely 2040s completion timeframe for large-scale nuclear generation, unless small modular reactors become viable.

On gas, there's virtually bipartisan support. The Coalition promise to reserve more gas for domestic use is a response to looming shortfalls on the east coast. Labor has also approved more coal and gas projects largely for export, though Australian coal and gas burned overseas aren't counted domestically.

Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has promised to include gas in Labor's renewable-oriented Capacity Investment Scheme and has floated relaxing the Safeguard Mechanism on heavy emitters. The Coalition has vowed to cancel plans for three offshore wind projects and are very critical of green hydrogen funding.

Both parties will likely introduce emission reduction measures, but a Coalition government would be less stringent. Scrapping corporate emissions reporting entirely would be a misstep, because accurate measurement of emissions are essential for attracting green investment and reducing climate risks.

Johanna Nalau has received funding from Australian Research Council for climate adaptation research, is a Lead Author of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Co-chair of the Science Committee of the World Adaptation Science Program (United Nations Environment Programme) and is a technical expert with United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

Madeline Taylor has received funding from the Australian Research Council, ACOLA, and several industry and government partners for energy transition research. She is a board member of REAlliance, Fellow of the Climate Council, and Honorary Associate of the Sydney Environment Institute.

Tony Wood may own shares in companies in relevant industries through his superannuation fund

urn:contentItem:6GJB-NDF3-RS1H-S2RJ-00000-00August 18, 2025: PwC Projects Middle East GDP to Reach $4.68 Trillion by 20352025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSAugust 18, 2025: PwC Projects Middle East GDP to Reach $4.68 Trillion by 2035

PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) has released a report indicating that the Middle East is on a trajectory to achieve a GDP of $4.68 trillion by 2035, contingent upon strategic policy adoption by regional governments. As stated by Stephen Anderson, chief strategy & technology officer at PwC Middle East, on 18th August 2025, the region must focus on coordinated policies that build trust, reduce risk, and align with long-term national priorities. These efforts should encompass responsible AI integration, climate adaptation, investment in human capital, and fostering trust in technology and institutions.

The 'Value in Motion' report outlines three possible futures for the Middle East, influenced by the region's navigation of AI adoption, climate action, and economic reinvention. The 'trust-based transformation' scenario presents the highest growth potential, projecting a GDP of $4.68 trillion, driven by effective collaboration and sustainability measures. In contrast, the 'tense transition' scenario anticipates a GDP of $4.61 trillion, while the 'turbulent times' scenario forecasts a GDP of $4.45 trillion, highlighting a $232 billion gap between the best and worst case outcomes. The report emphasizes that AI could contribute an additional 8.3% to GDP growth under the trust-based scenario, although decarbonization efforts may simultaneously reduce GDP by 5.2% due to stranded assets.

PwC notes that the Middle East's capacity to lead in solar power generation could provide additional benefits in decarbonization efforts. Emerging sectors such as green fuels, agritech, and renewable-powered data centers present untapped opportunities that could further enhance regional economic growth. The report posits that a trust-based transformation would see AI and climate solutions working in tandem to drive productivity growth and climate resilience. Conversely, the tense transition scenario depicts a more fragmented approach to sustainability and technology adoption, while the turbulent times scenario highlights the risks of geopolitical instability undermining trust in technology and limiting its economic benefits.

The report does not predict a fixed trajectory but offers a framework for assessing potential outcomes. Current trends in AI investment, renewable energy, and digital infrastructure align with elements of the trust-based transformation scenario. The future will ultimately depend on how effectively AI is harnessed, how Middle Eastern economies manage the energy transition, and the economic implications of decarbonization. Achieving the ambitious goal of a $4.68 trillion GDP requires a holistic approach focused on embedding AI responsibly, accelerating climate adaptation, and investing in human capital, as emphasized by PwC.

Furthermore, the report underscores the importance of establishing clear regulatory frameworks to bolster public confidence in AI. Public-private partnerships will be crucial in scaling energy and digital infrastructure, while targeted incentives can stimulate domestic innovation in critical areas such as AI chips and clean technology manufacturing. By prioritizing workforce development in AI education and green skills, the Middle East can ensure a steady pipeline of talent for future-ready industries. Ultimately, a trust-based, integrated approach to policy can unlock sustainable growth, productivity, and climate resilience, paving the way for the Middle East to achieve its ambitious GDP target by 2035.

urn:contentItem:6GHX-WP23-S6NY-G48C-00000-00August 18, 2025: PwC Projects Middle East GDP to Reach $4.68 Trillion by 20352025-08-19T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSAugust 18, 2025: PwC Projects Middle East GDP to Reach $4.68 Trillion by 2035

PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) has released a report indicating that the Middle East is on a trajectory to achieve a GDP of $4.68 trillion by 2035, contingent upon strategic policy adoption by regional governments. As stated by Stephen Anderson, chief strategy & technology officer at PwC Middle East, on 18th August 2025, the region must focus on coordinated policies that build trust, reduce risk, and align with long-term national priorities. These efforts should encompass responsible AI integration, climate adaptation, investment in human capital, and fostering trust in technology and institutions.

The 'Value in Motion' report outlines three possible futures for the Middle East, influenced by the region's navigation of AI adoption, climate action, and economic reinvention. The 'trust-based transformation' scenario presents the highest growth potential, projecting a GDP of $4.68 trillion, driven by effective collaboration and sustainability measures. In contrast, the 'tense transition' scenario anticipates a GDP of $4.61 trillion, while the 'turbulent times' scenario forecasts a GDP of $4.45 trillion, highlighting a $232 billion gap between the best and worst case outcomes. The report emphasizes that AI could contribute an additional 8.3% to GDP growth under the trust-based scenario, although decarbonization efforts may simultaneously reduce GDP by 5.2% due to stranded assets.

PwC notes that the Middle East's capacity to lead in solar power generation could provide additional benefits in decarbonization efforts. Emerging sectors such as green fuels, agritech, and renewable-powered data centers present untapped opportunities that could further enhance regional economic growth. The report posits that a trust-based transformation would see AI and climate solutions working in tandem to drive productivity growth and climate resilience. Conversely, the tense transition scenario depicts a more fragmented approach to sustainability and technology adoption, while the turbulent times scenario highlights the risks of geopolitical instability undermining trust in technology and limiting its economic benefits.

The report does not predict a fixed trajectory but offers a framework for assessing potential outcomes. Current trends in AI investment, renewable energy, and digital infrastructure align with elements of the trust-based transformation scenario. The future will ultimately depend on how effectively AI is harnessed, how Middle Eastern economies manage the energy transition, and the economic implications of decarbonization. Achieving the ambitious goal of a $4.68 trillion GDP requires a holistic approach focused on embedding AI responsibly, accelerating climate adaptation, and investing in human capital, as emphasized by PwC.

Furthermore, the report underscores the importance of establishing clear regulatory frameworks to bolster public confidence in AI. Public-private partnerships will be crucial in scaling energy and digital infrastructure, while targeted incentives can stimulate domestic innovation in critical areas such as AI chips and clean technology manufacturing. By prioritizing workforce development in AI education and green skills, the Middle East can ensure a steady pipeline of talent for future-ready industries. Ultimately, a trust-based, integrated approach to policy can unlock sustainable growth, productivity, and climate resilience, paving the way for the Middle East to achieve its ambitious GDP target by 2035.

1.1 ACTIVITIES

PricewaterhouseCoopers International Limited (PwC), headquartered in London, UK, is a leading global professional services network, formed in 1998 through the merger of Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand, with origins in the 19th century. A Big Four firm alongside Deloitte, EY, and KPMG, PwC operates in 140 countries with over 370,000 employees, offering assurance, tax, and advisory services. Its FY 2022 global revenue was $50.3 billion, with $18.0 billion from assurance, $11.6 billion from tax and legal, and $20.7 billion from advisory. PwCs assurance practice provides financial audits and risk management, while advisory services include strategy consulting, digital transformation, and cybersecurity. The tax division serves industries like technology and healthcare. Coordinated by a private company limited by guarantee, PwCs independent member firms adapt to local regulations. Serving 84% of Fortune 500 companies, PwC leverages AI, cloud technology, and ESG solutions. Despite a $229 million settlement in 2007 over Tycos accounting issues and criticism for tax avoidance strategies, PwC drives impact through projects like GEs transformation and healthcare initiatives in India, reinforcing its global influence.

urn:contentItem:6G5R-VCF3-SJX7-601N-00000-00Why investing in climate-vulnerable countries makes good business sense2025-07-02T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisWhy investing in climate-vulnerable countries makes good business senseAli Serim, Advisor for the Centre of Geopolitics of Global Change, ODI Global

Investing in climate adaptation is one of the smartest financial opportunities of our time

At a coastal port in Chittagong, Bangladesh, something remarkable is underway. With support from a US$850 million (£620 million) investment from the World Bank, engineers are building flood-resistant infrastructure that can survive rising seas and stronger storms. A new 3.7-mile-long barrier will protect people, homes, and trade in one of the world's most climate-vulnerable regions.

Projects like this do more than save lives. They show why investing in climate adaptation is one of the smartest financial opportunities of our time. There are plenty of global conferences where leaders discuss climate change and make big promises. Yet, less than 5.5% of global climate finance actually reaches the countries most at risk. That is not just a failure of fairness. It is a missed chance for real impact.

As the world gathers in Seville, Spain for the fourth international meeting on development financing, the focus must go beyond pledges and shift toward practical, on-the-ground investment in resilience.

At the previous UN climate finance meeting, also held in Seville, leaders focused on fixing how public money flows through global institutions. But just as important is the need to invest in climate adaptation. This means helping people live with the changes already happening, including more floods, longer droughts, rising seas and intense heat.

While mitigation is about stopping climate change getting worse (by switching to clean energy or protecting forests that absorb carbon, for example), adaptation is about coping with the effects we can no longer avoid. It includes building stronger homes, growing more resilient crops, and improving hospitals and schools so they can keep working during extreme weather. Both approaches are necessary, but adaptation often gets less attention. And less money.

Private investors have already committed large sums to clean energy projects. But they have done much less to support communities on the frontlines of climate change. Many of these countries struggle with limited budgets, complex rules for accessing finance, and a lack of support to develop viable projects. So promising ideas often go unfunded.

That is beginning to change. New tools are helping investors take on less risk and back more projects. These include low-interest loans, partnerships between public and private institutions, and guarantees that reduce the risk of failure.

The Green Climate Fund is the largest source of dedicated climate finance for developing countries. By the end of 2023, it had approved US$13.5 billion in funding, rising to US$51.9 billion when co-financing is included. This money helps unlock adaptation efforts that were previously out of reach.

We can already see progress. In Kenya and Ethiopia, farmers are using drought-resistant seeds to grow more food in changing conditions. In the Caribbean, solar energy is powering schools and clinics in remote communities. And in Bangladesh, the new port infrastructure in Chittagong is protecting a vital economic hub while boosting local businesses.

Working with nature

In coastal areas, restoring mangrove forests can reduce the force of incoming storms, protect biodiversity and support fisheries. The Pollination Group, a climate investment firm, is helping turn "nature-based solutions" like these into projects that attract private finance.

In his previous role as the Prince of Wales, King Charles III launched the Natural Capital Investment Alliance, an initiative that aims to mobilise US$10 billion for projects that restore and protect nature while offering solid financial returns. The alliance also helps investors better understand these kinds of opportunities by creating clearer guidance and standards. This supports the Terra Carta, a charter created by King Charles III that offers a roadmap for businesses to align with the needs of both people and the planet by 2030.

Investors who step into these emerging spaces gain more than financial returns. They build long-term relationships with governments and local communities. They help shape future policy. And they create lasting foundations for growth in places that are ready to lead if given the chance.

Adaptation projects also bring real benefits to people. They improve access to clean water, protect food supplies, create jobs, strengthen education and support healthcare systems. For families already facing climate disruption, these changes are not just improvements. They are lifelines.

By creating stable and welcoming environments for responsible investment, governments can accelerate this shift. By simplifying how money is accessed, international institutions can make it easier for good ideas to become funded projects. Philanthropic groups and development agencies can help build local skills and prepare projects for funding. Private investors can bring capital, innovation and experience.

Investing in climate adaptation is no longer just a moral issue. It is a smart, scalable and necessary response to a changing world.

urn:contentItem:6GGN-YNN3-RS6H-512C-00000-00Winning the war on weeds2025-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisNone34Winning the war on weeds

New CSIRO research is highlighting how grain and cotton growers are making significant productivity gains through long-term weed management strategies, demonstrating that weeds can be effectively controlled.

A decade on from the last national estimate, new CSIRO research, funded by the Grains Research and Development Corporation (GRDC) and Cotton Research and Development Corporation (CRDC), has found that weeds cost the grain and cotton industries an estimated $4.43 billion per year.

Taking into account inflation and adjusted values, this is a seven per cent increase in costs for grain growers; however, despite this increase in costs, growers are reaping the rewards of their investment.

Through proactive management and innovation, the impact of weeds on crop yield has fallen, from 2.8 million tonnes in 2016 to 1.2 million tonnes in 2025, translating into higher production and income.

Rick Llewellyn, CSIRO research scientist who co-authored the report led by Jackie Ouzman, said weed control remains one of the biggest annual costs for growers, but the investment is paying off.

"By staying ahead of the weed seed bank, resistance and adopting smarter, more targeted practices, growers are protecting long-term profitability and enabling flexibility in their system," he said.

Australian growers lead the way with integrated weed management, combining pre-emergent herbicides, harvest weed seed control, crop rotation, and new precision technologies such as camera-guided spraying.

One of the biggest gains comes from improved summer fallow weed control, which helps conserve valuable soil moisture and supports better crop establishment in drier seasons, an essential part of farming in a changing climate.

"Effective weed control is a critical part of climate adaptation," Dr Llewellyn said.

"With increasingly variable rainfall and larger cropping programs, growers need to sow crops when conditions are right without delays for weed control."

The 2025 study also includes cotton production for the first time, offering a fuller picture of weed impacts across Australia's two largest cropping sectors.

Weeds cost producers on average $4.3 billion ($203 per ha) in grain crops and $145 million ($445 per hectare) in cotton crops, with cotton growers shown to invest heavily in keeping weed densities exceptionally low.

"Australian growers are showing global leadership in weed management, but the cost increases are real. We need to keep supporting research and find ways to stay ahead of evolving weed challenges while also reducing these costs," Dr Llewellyn said.

urn:contentItem:6GJB-NDF3-RS1H-S2TG-00000-00August 12, 2025: Arizona Board of Regents Takes Action Amid Drought Concerns2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSAugust 12, 2025: Arizona Board of Regents Takes Action Amid Drought Concerns

As concerns about Arizona's water future grow, the Arizona Board of Regents (ABOR) and the state's public universities are collaborating to safeguard groundwater resources. On 12th December 2025, it was announced that a Regents' Grant is funding the Arizona Tri-University Recharge and Water Reliability Project, aimed at addressing the pressing issue of water scarcity in the region.

Kathy Jacobs, a professor of environmental science at the University of Arizona and director of the Center for Climate Adaptation Science and Solutions, highlighted the urgency of the situation. The Arizona Department of Water Resources has tasked the project team with developing methods to capture precipitation and runoff before it evaporates, thereby replenishing the state's aquifers. "The reason that's a big issue is that more than 95% of the water that falls on the ground either as snow or rain in Arizona evaporates back into the atmosphere," Jacobs stated. She emphasized that capturing even a small percentage of this water could significantly benefit rural areas.

Groundwater currently accounts for approximately 40% of Arizona's water supply, yet its monitoring remains intricate, particularly in sparsely populated regions. According to Jacobs, the project employs some of the most advanced modeling techniques available in the state and potentially the United States. "We're using machine learning and the national water model, along with locally adjusted models that examine the entire hydrologic cycle in great detail," she explained. This innovative approach allows for the generation of new insights into the water cycle across every watershed in Arizona, a level of detail not previously accessible.

The Arizona Board of Regents underscored the importance of this initiative in a press release, describing it as a scientific foundation for water reliability amid prolonged drought conditions and declining allocations from the Colorado River. The landscapes across the state are experiencing unprecedented stress, characterized by low soil moisture, drought-affected vegetation, and increased fire danger. This collaborative effort aims to address these critical challenges and ensure sustainable water management for future generations.

As Arizona grapples with the realities of climate change and water scarcity, the proactive measures being taken by the Arizona Board of Regents and its partner universities are vital. The success of the Tri-University Recharge and Water Reliability Project may serve as a model for other regions facing similar environmental challenges, demonstrating the importance of innovation and collaboration in safeguarding natural resources.

urn:contentItem:6G9X-9HP3-RRRX-R3Y9-00000-00Tuvalu citizens keen to flee rising waters2025-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisNATIONPg. 10Tuvalu citizens keen to flee rising watersBrendan Kearns

More than half of the citizens of Tuvalu have applied for a visa to permanently migrate to Australia.

Just more than a month ago, Australia opened The Falepili Mobility Pathway ballot, a program to provide citizens of the tiny island nation of Tuvalu a permanent migration pathway.

The country has a population of 10,643, 5157 of whom entered the lottery. This was through 1466 registrations, with many of the people being included as family members on applications.

The ballot, which closed on Friday, randomly selects up to 280 people each year to apply for the visa.

It is open to all Tuvalu citizens, and visa holders do not need to gain employment in Australia before applying.

Selections for the ballot will take place between July 25, 2025 and January 25, 2026.

The scheme allows successful applicants to live, work and study anywhere in Australia indefinitely, sponsor relatives to also migrate and apply for citizenship once eligible.

The island nation is particularly exposed to the effects of climate change, with this program providing a path to flee as the impacts worsen.

The pathway is part of the Australia-Tuvalu Falepili Union that both countries signed on August 28, 2024.

Also included in the union is a commitment of $38m to invest in climate adaptation measures on the island. When the ballot opened last month, Pacific Island Affairs Minister Pat Conroy called it the "most significant agreement" between Australia and a Pacific country since PNG's independence in 1975.

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) is pleased to welcome Advocate Duma Boko, President of the Republic of Botswana to its Board, bringing to the table a renewed focus on climate justice, sustainable development and homegrown solutions for a continent on the frontline of the climate crisis.

+ GCA LAUNCHED CO-DESIGN WORKSHOP IN NAIROBI TO ADVANCE URBAN CLIMATE RESILIENCE IN SOMALIA

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA), in collaboration with the World Bank, Somali government partners and GCA's training partner RedR UK, launched a multi-day Co-Design Workshop in Nairobi today to support climate-resilient urban development in Somalia. The workshop marks a key milestone in co-developing the Urban Climate Resilience Masterclass (UCRMC), a flagship training program designed to strengthen institutional capacity for climate adaptation in Somali cities.

Source: Company Website

+ GCA COMMENDS HOMA BAY'S LEADERSHIP IN CLIMATE RESILIENCE AS PEOPLE'S ADAPTATION PLAN INTEGRATED WITH COUNTY PLANNING

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) today hailed Homa Bay County's bold leadership in transforming community-led climate action into official county planning, following a two-day visit by GCA President and CEO Professor Patrick V. Verkooijen to the lakeside county. His visit celebrated the integration of the People's Adaptation Plan into Homa Bay's official Local Physical and Land Use Development Plan-a landmark for locally led adaptation in Kenya. The visit, which included meetings with community leaders, informal traders, youth, and county officials, comes ahead of the formal launch of the People's Adaptation Plan in August, where Professor Verkooijen will participate in Kenya's Devolution Conference to showcase the model nationally.

Source: Company Website

+ GLOBAL CENTER ON ADAPTATION: TOGO ADVANCES NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL INSURANCE WITH GCA SUPPORT

The Government of Togo, in partnership with the Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) and Bioversity International and CIAT, has taken a major step forward in strengthening climate resilience for its farmers through the co-development of a National Agricultural Insurance Roadmap.

At a two-day workshop held in Lome on 10-11 July 2025, key stakeholders from across Togo's agriculture sector came together to finalize a comprehensive roadmap that will guide the rollout of index-based insurance for farmers. Participants included farming cooperatives, insurance providers, technical institutions, financial partners, and public agencies, all of whom contributed to a shared vision for a climate-smart agricultural insurance system.

urn:contentItem:6GJC-57B3-RRVN-J0C8-00000-00August 16, 2025: UNM's ARID Institute Secures $7 Million Grant for Watershed Management Innovation2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSAugust 16, 2025: UNM's ARID Institute Secures $7 Million Grant for Watershed Management Innovation

The University of New Mexico's Accelerating Resilience Innovations in Drylands (ARID) Institute has received a significant boost in funding to enhance watershed management across the state. A four-year, $7 million grant from the National Science Foundation (NSF) through the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) program was awarded on 16th August 2025. This funding aims to establish a comprehensive network that will unite researchers, land managers, and communities in New Mexico, focusing on sustainable forest and watershed management.

New Mexico's forested watersheds are vital for water supply, carbon storage, and cultural significance, yet they are increasingly threatened by climate change, wildfires, and competing land uses. The most affected areas include the Rio Grande and Pecos River Basins, which primarily serve Indigenous and rural communities reliant on surface water for agriculture and daily life. The combined effects of diminishing snowpack, fluctuating precipitation patterns, and intensified wildfire activity present significant challenges for watershed management, making this initiative timely and necessary.

The NSF EPSCoR Research Incubators for STEM Excellence (E-RISE-RII) project, titled 'Forest Research for New Mexico Water and Carbon Management' (FOR-NM), intends to integrate expertise from various fields. By combining knowledge in ecology, hydrology, remote sensing, and machine learning with social sciences, the project aims to provide actionable insights into watershed management. Lead Principal Investigator Marcy Litvak, a UNM Biology Professor, emphasized the project's dual focus on gathering critical ecological data and fostering economic and workforce development through community engagement.

FOR-NM will target New Mexico's Top 500 priority watersheds and will utilize advanced technologies such as high-resolution satellite data and machine learning models to evaluate forest management impacts. The initiative will monitor two watersheds intensively, including the Santa Fe Watershed, to examine how management practices influence hydrologic connectivity and ecological outcomes. This research will also pilot a Guided Transformation framework that merges scientific findings with community needs, aiming to deliver practical climate-adaptation solutions.

The ARID Institute at the University of New Mexico is poised to set a precedent in forest, water, and carbon management not only within the state but also as a model for similar ecosystems in the Southwestern United States and globally. The collaboration includes partners such as New Mexico State University and the Asombro Institute for Science Education, highlighting the initiative's comprehensive approach to addressing the urgent challenges posed by climate change.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY [4 Press Releases]

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY SECURES $5.8 MILLION FOR HEALTH RESEARCH INITIATIVES

Queen's University has been awarded a total of $5.8 million in funding from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) for six research projects that aim to enhance patient care, promote health equity, and foster innovative therapies. The funding comprises five Project Grants, which support research led by investigators in various health domains, along with one Priority Announcement award. The Priority Announcements fund initiatives that are in line with certain national research objectives set by CIHR, such as bolstering primary care or expanding access to preventive health services. Out of a competitive field of 2,814 applications across the country, these six projects from Queen's were selected as part of only 435 that received CIHR funding.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS BRIDGE SCIENCE AND POLICY

In Ontario's legislature, researchers are discovering innovative ways to influence public policy. This spring, Dr. Ryan Grant from Electrical and Computer Engineering and Dr. Yanwen Zhang from Mechanical and Materials Engineering represented Queen's University at the first-ever Science Meets Parliament Ontario. This initiative aims to connect scientists with provincial lawmakers to enhance the integration of research into policymaking. Organized by the Canadian Science Policy Centre, the program allows academic researchers to interact with Members of Provincial Parliament (MPPs) and legislative staff, participate in question period, and engage in workshops focused on science communication and public involvement. For Drs. Grant and Zhang, this was a chance to link their research efforts to pressing issues on Ontario's policy agenda.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY HOSTS EDVARD MUNCH EXHIBITION DELVING INTO THEMES OF ILLNESS AND CARE

Norwegian artist Edvard Munch, celebrated for his iconic painting The Scream, dedicated his career to examining the emotional and physical challenges faced by the human body. A new exhibition titled Lifeblood at the MUNCH museum in Oslo connects his artworks with historical medical artifacts, reflecting on his personal experiences with illness and care. It also aims to address the complexities of health and sickness, as well as the cycles of birth and death, highlighting the dynamics of giving and receiving care. Curated by Allison Morehead, a professor at Queen's University, this exhibition is the result of extensive research in both art history and the medical humanities. It opened its doors on June 27, 2025, and is projected to attract over 250,000 visitors before concluding on September 21, 2025.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY PIONEERS INNOVATIVE APPROACHES TO SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE

If you've ever looked up at the Queen's Biosciences Complex and wondered about the greenhouse perched on its roof, you're not alone. This plant haven is part of the Queen's University Phytotron - a state-of-the-art research facility dedicated to advanced plant science research and operated by the Department of Biology. The Phytotron features six climate-controlled greenhouse zones, 30 environmental growth chambers, and a lab. Each area is designed to replicate a vast array of environmental conditions, including temperature, humidity, CO levels, air flow, and light quality. + QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY [4 Press Releases]

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY SECURES $5.8 MILLION FOR HEALTH RESEARCH INITIATIVES

Queen's University has been awarded a total of $5.8 million in funding from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) for six research projects that aim to enhance patient care, promote health equity, and foster innovative therapies. The funding comprises five Project Grants, which support research led by investigators in various health domains, along with one Priority Announcement award. The Priority Announcements fund initiatives that are in line with certain national research objectives set by CIHR, such as bolstering primary care or expanding access to preventive health services. Out of a competitive field of 2,814 applications across the country, these six projects from Queen's were selected as part of only 435 that received CIHR funding.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS BRIDGE SCIENCE AND POLICY

In Ontario's legislature, researchers are discovering innovative ways to influence public policy. This spring, Dr. Ryan Grant from Electrical and Computer Engineering and Dr. Yanwen Zhang from Mechanical and Materials Engineering represented Queen's University at the first-ever Science Meets Parliament Ontario. This initiative aims to connect scientists with provincial lawmakers to enhance the integration of research into policymaking. Organized by the Canadian Science Policy Centre, the program allows academic researchers to interact with Members of Provincial Parliament (MPPs) and legislative staff, participate in question period, and engage in workshops focused on science communication and public involvement. For Drs. Grant and Zhang, this was a chance to link their research efforts to pressing issues on Ontario's policy agenda.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY HOSTS EDVARD MUNCH EXHIBITION DELVING INTO THEMES OF ILLNESS AND CARE

Norwegian artist Edvard Munch, celebrated for his iconic painting The Scream, dedicated his career to examining the emotional and physical challenges faced by the human body. A new exhibition titled Lifeblood at the MUNCH museum in Oslo connects his artworks with historical medical artifacts, reflecting on his personal experiences with illness and care. It also aims to address the complexities of health and sickness, as well as the cycles of birth and death, highlighting the dynamics of giving and receiving care. Curated by Allison Morehead, a professor at Queen's University, this exhibition is the result of extensive research in both art history and the medical humanities. It opened its doors on June 27, 2025, and is projected to attract over 250,000 visitors before concluding on September 21, 2025.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY PIONEERS INNOVATIVE APPROACHES TO SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE

If you've ever looked up at the Queen's Biosciences Complex and wondered about the greenhouse perched on its roof, you're not alone. This plant haven is part of the Queen's University Phytotron - a state-of-the-art research facility dedicated to advanced plant science research and operated by the Department of Biology. The Phytotron features six climate-controlled greenhouse zones, 30 environmental growth chambers, and a lab. Each area is designed to replicate a vast array of environmental conditions, including temperature, humidity, CO levels, air flow, and light quality. The facility's conservatory boasts more than 150 tropical plant species that facilitate research across various fields, including plant biology, agriculture, climate adaptation, and global food security.

urn:contentItem:6GJ0-SDS3-RTBN-G4R9-00000-00New Roadmap to help guide sustainable growth of Queensland’s intensive animal industries: QFF2025-08-19T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisNew Roadmap to help guide sustainable growth of Queensland’s intensive animal industries: QFF

Queensland Farmers’ Federation (QFF), Media Release, 19 August 2025

Queensland’s intensive animal industries have released a 10-year roadmap that sets a clear and collaborative pathway for future growth, resilience, and sustainability across the sector, while supporting food security for Queenslanders and Australia.

Link to Image

The Intensive Animal Industries Queensland Roadmap 2025–2035outlines a strategic, industry-led plan for managing the challenges and opportunities facing Queensland’s pork, poultry (eggs and chicken meat), dairy and feedlot sectors.

Together, these industries collectively contribute close to $1.75 billion annually to the state economy and provide more than 50 per cent of Queenslanders’ daily protein intake.

The roadmap was developed through extensive consultation between industry leaders, government, researchers and peak bodies, including the Queensland Farmers’ Federation (QFF), and with funding support from the Queensland Government.

The roadmap identifies four key focus areas for the decade ahead: Land Use Planning and Management, Animal Health, Welfare and Biosecurity, Market Demand and Supply, and Value-Based Food Production.

QFF CEO Jo Sheppard said the roadmap reflects the importance of planning now to secure future food production and food security in Queensland and nationally.

“The intensive animals industries are incredibly important for food security and the supply of protein to Queensland, Australian and global consumers.”

“This roadmap is an example of Queensland’s intensive animal industries working together collectively to find solutions to the shared challenges facing their sector, and proactively identifying a unified pathway forward,” Ms Sheppard said.

“With the global population expected to reach nearly 10 billion by 2050, the pressure to produce more protein sustainably is growing. These industries are amongst the most innovative and agile in the world but face complex issues ranging from land use and emissions reduction to biosecurity and market demand.

“This document is both a strategic foundation and a living plan that will evolve as the sector navigates change, builds resilience, and strives for value-based, sustainable and profitable growth.”

Department of Primary Industries Deputy Director-General Ash Bacon said the roadmap supports Primary Industries Prosper 2050 – the Queensland Government’s 25-year blueprint co-designed with industry to shape a thriving future for Queensland and our primary industries. 

“Queensland’s intensive animal industries are essential to our state’s food security and economic success, particularly in regional areas,” said Mr Bacon.

“This roadmap ensures government and industry remain aligned in navigating challenges like climate adaptation, land and water use competition, and sustainable production. We’re proud to have supported this initiative and look forward to ongoing collaboration.”

The roadmap process brought together industry leaders who recognised shared challenges and the need for coordinated action. A series of workshops helped shape the roadmap’s key pillars, ensuring broad representation from across industry, academia, and government.

The roadmap is also a timely contribution to the broader discussion around the role of agriculture in securing Australia’s food future, particularly as environmental targets, shifting consumer expectations, and global supply chain pressures reshape the operating landscape.

“Planning for the future of food requires a long-term vision,” Ms Sheppard said.

“This roadmap gives us that and puts industry at the heart of the solution.”

urn:contentItem:6G30-9S43-RRWS-00N9-00000-00Making sustainability easy for SMEs2025-06-17T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisADVERTISING FEATUREPg. 6Making sustainability easy for SMEs

For many small and medium enterprises, adopting sustainable business practices can be another load on their already busy business life.

EcoBiz, a sustainability program delivered by Business Chamber Queensland, aims to arm SMEs with the sustainability tools to not simply survive in an ever-changing landscape, but thrive.

"We've been around for 157 years; we know business," says Business Chamber Queensland chief executive Heidi Cooper. "We've taken our deep understanding of business to develop a sustainability program that is designed by business for business and gets real business outcomes.

"The most rewarding thing with the whole ecoBiz program is when you hear people say, 'I didn't know I could do these things. I didn't know what was possible.' And we see businesses go from strength to strength."

Delivered in partnership with the Queensland government, ecoBiz has been helping businesses adopt sustainable practices for the past decade.

Free to participants with fewer than 200 full-time equivalent staff, it has helped Queensland businesses avoid more than $3.15 million in energy, water and waste costs in 2023-24, and 12,077 tonnes of carbon emissions.

"Unfortunately, natural disasters have become a part of business life in Queensland," Cooper says. "That's why we have developed a Climate Adaptation module to help businesses be more resilient and establish business continuity practices ahead of the impacts of a natural disaster and climate shocks."

The June launch of the Climate Adaptation module adds another vital layer to a sophisticated program that meets businesses where they are at in their sustainability journey, and opens their eyes to the myriad opportunities that engaging in this space present.

"We've seen some of the most challenging operating environments in decades," Cooper says. "Businesses need a direct outcome, a saving around their energy, waste and water costs, and practical measures to support their business, alongside future-focused measures like supply chain, procurement and export readiness.

"But what we're also working on is: How do they get a compounding impact? How do they enable their employees to think differently? How do they see that behavioural change? How do they increase productivity? How do they think differently about innovation and a circular economy?"

Engaging with ecoBiz to help future-proof your business is simple. A five-minute online quiz indicates your business's sustainability maturity level - ranging from emerging, to developing, accelerating or maturing. Relevant articles and videos help build knowledge that is tailored to your needs, then the assessment tool identifies specific challenges and opportunities.

An action plan maps out steps to be taken in time frames that are stipulated by the business, and an implementation dashboard tracks progress as the steps are put in place, all with ecoBiz's support.

For Cooper, the most rewarding feedback is from business owners who aren't just being directed to a website and expected to work it out for themselves. They like that ecoBiz's programs are curated specifically for them, by people with SME experience who understand their challenges - and the opportunities they can present.

"This isn't a cookie-cutter, it's designed for their business," Cooper says. "We know businesses have more than enough on their plate, so we do that hard work for them so the program meets them where they're at, and builds their maturity the whole way through."

Olenka Muzik is publican of the Euramo Hotel, inland from Mission Beach and widely known as The Yacht Club because locals head there in their tinnies when the Tully River floods. The pub is on higher ground, and acts as a vital community gathering place when disaster strikes.

"I'm lucky that I've always made sure I've got enough stock to last me a couple of weeks if something goes wrong," Muzik says.

With the road between Townsville and Cairns cut off for 18 days already this year, exploring supply chain opportunities is becoming increasingly vital.

Muzik was googling ways of saving on power bills when she found ecoBiz, and was keen to discover how it might help future-proof the pub.

Through the ecoBiz program, the Euramo Hotel has already saved on its energy, waste and water and implemented practical steps to establish more sustainable practices.

Now the business is keen to be a part of the newly released Climate Adaptation module so it can look at ways to better prepare for natural disasters and put in place long-term business continuity practices.

EcoBiz program manager Catie Simmons says the Euramo Hotel offers a great example of the bespoke and interactive nature of the climate risk assessment tool. Muzik can simply click on her area of Far North Queensland to access the latest climate projection data showing likely changes in the region.

"We want to leave businesses with something that can help them prepare for future changes," Simmons says. "We want them to feel empowered."

Cooper encourages SMEs to take the time during "normal" operation to prepare themselves and their staff for the changing climate ahead.

"We're super-excited to be launching the Climate Adaptation module," she says. "It has never been more important for Queensland businesses to prepare for potential natural disasters, and we are so proud to be able to support them to manage through what can be some of the most challenging times."

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) today hailed Homa Bay County's bold leadership in transforming community-led climate action into official county planning, following a two-day visit by GCA President and CEO Professor Patrick V. Verkooijen to the lakeside county. His visit celebrated the integration of the People's Adaptation Plan into Homa Bay's official Local Physical and Land Use Development Plan-a landmark for locally led adaptation in Kenya. The visit, which included meetings with community leaders, informal traders, youth, and county officials, comes ahead of the formal launch of the People's Adaptation Plan in August, where Professor Verkooijen will participate in Kenya's Devolution Conference to showcase the model nationally.

The Government of Togo, in partnership with the Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) and Bioversity International and CIAT, has taken a major step forward in strengthening climate resilience for its farmers through the co-development of a National Agricultural Insurance Roadmap.

At a two-day workshop held in Lome on 10-11 July 2025, key stakeholders from across Togo's agriculture sector came together to finalize a comprehensive roadmap that will guide the rollout of index-based insurance for farmers. Participants included farming cooperatives, insurance providers, technical institutions, financial partners, and public agencies, all of whom contributed to a shared vision for a climate-smart agricultural insurance system.

urn:contentItem:6GCD-3S53-RS79-83NX-00000-00Rollerskate coach gets a Greens light2025-07-29T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Rollerskate coach gets a Greens lightThomas McLean

Ellyane Wall has been endorsed by the Northern Territory Greens as part of her bid to run as a councillor for the City of Darwin's Chan Ward.

It marks the first public endorsement from any political party in the City of Darwin thus far in the 2025 election campaign.

In a statement, the NT Greens said Ms Wall was "passionate about climate action, accessibility and inclusion, participatory democracy, and youth representation".

Ms Wall volunteers with Rapid Creek Landcare and Birdlife NT, and she works as a rollerskating coach.

Chan Ward comprises the suburbs of Coconut Grove, East Point, Fannie Bay, Jingili, Ludmilla, Millner, Nightcliff and Rapid Creek.

Current councillor Morgan Rickard, who represents Chan Ward, was backed by the NT Greens in the 2021 local government elections, which he won in.

More recently, NT Greens candidate Kat McNamara narrowly won the electorate of Nightcliff in the 2024 NT Election.

Ms Wall said in a statement that Darwin was "my favourite place on Earth". "I'm running for council because I want to make sure that my generation feels that they can build their futures here," she said.

"I love our community, our town, and our unique way of life. Serving on council is an opportunity for me to give back to the community that has so fundamentally shaped who I am today.

"Council is so much more than rates, roads and rubbish. Our councils make decisions that impact everyone's experience of our community for years to come.

"I will be a strong voice for young people in our city, who are currently so under represented on council.

"As a councillor I would push for Darwin to become a leader in climate adaptation and sustainability. Our city has so much potential in this space -â€ƒwe just need the ambition to make it happen.

"I want to see our council investing in public spaces that are accessible, green and safe.

"I will advocate for investment in spaces and programs to engage at-risk young people and people with a disability. "Darwin should be a city that enables everyone to feel that they belong here."

urn:contentItem:6F1W-7GJ3-RRPW-4000-00000-00Postgrads enter climate workforce looking for a clean start2025-07-02T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisPostgrads enter climate workforce looking for a clean startChristopher Niesche

Demand for workers with climate skills is already increasing, as more job postings specifically cover adapting to the green transition.

Universities around Australia are offering postgraduate degrees to students wishing to join the expanding climate change-related workforce or incorporate climate change into their existing roles.

A government report from 2023 - The Clean Energy Generation, Workforce needs for a net zero economy - outlines 38 critical clean energy occupations, that will enjoy strong job growth. An extra 240,000 will be needed in the next seven years, with much of the demand coming from regional Australia.

Along with technicians and tradespeople, the in-demand occupations include professions in fields such as engineering; agriculture, fisheries and forestry; environmental science; geology and geophysics; and occupation and environmental health. Managers in policy and planning; construction; and engineering will also be required.

Link to Image

Paul Harris

Johanna Nalau, the program director of the Master of Climate Change Adaptation at Griffith University, says demand for workers with climate skills is already increasing, with a larger number of job postings specifically for climate change adaptation.

"Adaptation really goes across all levels of government, private sector - pretty much all the sectors will have to think about climate adaptation," she says.

The workforce is under-prepared because of a lack of investment in training and a lot of people have had to learn the required skills on the job.

"That was one of the driving factors why Griffith University thought, well, we have really strong expertise in climate change adaptation, so a few years ago we started offering the Masters of Climate Adaptation," Nalau says.

The university also offers a Graduate Certificate in Climate Change Adaptation - a one-year upskilling program.

Students for the graduate certificate come from a wide variety of backgrounds, from law, health, biodiversity, agriculture and civil society organisations.

Some of the students take the skills they have learned back to their current roles.

"Some of them do find new opportunities, specifically in climate adaptation and climate change jobs as well, but at the moment it's been quite a big focus on the upskilling and then enabling their own organisations to actually start doing climate adaptation," Nalau says.

Demand for the courses has increased steadily each year.

"It's because we are seeing climate impacts and we are seeing in the news heatwaves in places in Australia where we didn't used to have heatwaves," she says. "We're seeing increases in floods, increasing extreme events and really big changes. I think that's alerted a lot of organisations as well that this is the skill set that we would really need to start looking at."

The University of Queensland offers a Master of Environmental Management.

Although the degree doesn't specifically target climate change, course co-ordinator Philip Stewart says global warming is such a driving force on the environment that it is incorporated into many of the course's subjects.

For instance, Stewart teaches the Foundations of Environmental Studies unit, which incorporates the impacts of climate changes, such as snow melts. The Environmental Impact Assessment course also covers climate change because it needs to be brought into environmental impact assessments.

Additionally, there are specific climate change modules, offering students the chance to shape their degree to focus on global warming.

The Climate Change and Environmental Management course covers the different parts of the climate system - atmosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, biosphere and lithosphere - and explores the evidence for human-influenced climate change globally and in Australia.

It discusses the consequences and risks that climate change presents to the society, environment, ecosystems and biodiversity, and the potential strategies to mitigate and adapt for a future warmer world.

Graduate certificates

Students with a degree in disciplines including environmental studies, geography and natural resources can move straight into the 1½-year masters course, while those without the qualifications can start with the Graduate Certificate in Environmental Management, then move to the Graduate Diploma, before completing the masters.

Most domestic students take the degree as mature-aged students, some of them seeking a career change to move into government departments of the environment, parks and wildlife services, and mining regulatory and compliance organisations. Others end up in consultancies.

Along with a Master of Climate Science, the University of Melbourne offers a Graduate Certificate in Climate Change and Health.

"We developed the Graduate Certificate in Climate Change and Health primarily to target health professionals and graduates who have a particular interest in climate change and its intersection with health," says Kathryn Bowen, deputy director (knowledge exchange and policy impact) at Melbourne Climate Futures and Professor of Environment, Climate and Global Health.

"It's also for anyone working in health-determining sectors as well, for example agriculture, water, disaster management, finance and so on."

The Climate Change and Health unit covers the fundamental links between climate, climate change and human health, and equips students to critically evaluate and analyse how climate change impacts health outcomes, particularly in relation to vulnerable populations. They should also be able to plan a climate change mitigation or adaptation strategy to improve health outcomes.

"Students learn about the challenges, as well as solutions, including health services delivery," Bowen says. "They also learn about the need to effectively communicate the science behind climate change and health to educate and empower them to address these issues."

The course also teaches sustainability in healthcare, with real-world examples of how health workforces, clinicians and hospitals are seeking to change practices and become more sustainable and environmentally aware.

"That may be through tackling the huge amount of waste the health industry creates or looking at their contribution to the carbon footprint and environmental harms, and how they can make changes," Bowen says.

"It's truly a hands-on course where students walk away with the skills to assess and measure climate change impacts on health, as well as being able to analyse strategies and policies to reduce climate change and its effects on the global population."

Fundamental pillars

Students in the Master of Energy Change at The Australian National University are taught the fundamental pillars of knowledge to lead the energy transition, says course co-convener Igor Skryabin.

They need to learn about the technologies on a fundamental level, which incorporates fundamental physics.

"It's not technical skills. It's understanding of the science underlying all modern energy technology. And that's also to deal with quite widespread energy illiteracy," he says.

"If you understand the fundamental physics, you would quickly understand this certain project is just impossible because it breaches certain laws of physics. You can breach legislation and go to jail, but you cannot fundamentally breach the laws of physics, whatever you do."

Even so, students also need to learn about policy formation and legal systems.

"The way of thinking and considering issues by lawyers, judges may be very different from the way engineers and scientists deal with issues. So that's where they need to bridge this gap," says Skryabin.

The third pillar students need to learn is economics.

It's not enough for leaders of the energy transition to rely on experts in particular fields to provide them with advice. First, they need to find an expert and to be able to judge their advice.

The course attracts students from a range of backgrounds.

"Some of them are lawyers, some finance people, some are economists and some small fractions are engineers or scientists. We need to bring them over in one room together, right, and educate them together," he says.

Johanna Nalau, the program director of the Master of Climate Change Adaptation at Griffith University, says the workforce is under-prepared because of a lack of investment in training.

urn:contentItem:6GJB-V2S3-RV89-P0NG-00000-00August 19, 2025: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation Commits $2.5 Billion to Women's Health2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSAugust 19, 2025: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation Commits $2.5 Billion to Women's Health

In a landmark announcement, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will invest $2.5 billion in women's health over the next five years. This commitment, revealed on August 4th, 2025, marks one of the organization's largest financial pledges to date, aimed at addressing long-overlooked health conditions affecting women worldwide.

Bill Gates emphasized the urgency of this investment, stating, "Too many health conditions that affect women, including preeclampsia, endometriosis, and menopause, have been overlooked for far too long." He further noted that enhancing women's health can lead to improved family health, stronger economies, and a more equitable society. Gates expressed concern that women's health remains underfunded and sidelined, with too many preventable deaths occurring.

The funding will target five key areas, with the foundation aiming to boost research, develop innovative products, and ensure they are accessible globally. Dr. Anita Zaidi, who leads gender equality efforts at the Gates Foundation, highlighted the dire need for focused research in women's health. "For too long, women have suffered from health conditions that are misunderstood, misdiagnosed, or ignored," she stated in the news release. This investment seeks to ignite a new era of innovation prioritizing women's health in research and development.

Zaidi also pointed to a startling statistic regarding the lack of research on women's health, revealing that only a handful of women have been studied in significant health-related research. While the $2.5 billion investment is substantial, she described it as "a drop in the bucket," urging other philanthropists, governments, and private entities to join in the effort to close the funding gap in women's health.

The announcement comes as Bill Gates continues his philanthropic journey, with plans to donate his entire $200 billion fortune by 2045. Meanwhile, Melinda French Gates, who departed from the foundation last year, has been pursuing her initiatives focused on women's health, further amplifying the importance of this sector. As the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation takes this bold step, the call for broader support in women's health innovation remains paramount.

The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, founded in 2000 by Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates, is a global philanthropic organization headquartered in Seattle, Washington. urn:contentItem:6GF6-5B43-RWR0-84H5-00000-00Wariness over private water and property policies that impact landholders2025-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisWariness over private water and property policies that impact landholdersMel Williams

Advocate calls on ag sector not to take water rights for granted.

Water is the forgotten resource.

But there are a range of threats and opportunities when it comes to private water and property rights.

Western Australian Water Users Coalition (WAWUC) executive officer Doug Hall said there were many water policy issues that rural real estate agents needed to be aware of, but these were often neglected because of their complexity.

He said WAWUC was formed in 1998 to protect and promote the rights of water users, especially those relying on springfed dams, runoff and unlicensed surface water, in the face of evolving State water legislation.

The members of the apolitical WAWUC body are individual businesses and nine industry peak bodies, including those advocating for farmers.

Mr Hall said some of the key guiding principles of the organisation were private property rights, rule of law, self-interest, self-reliance, free markets and competition.

He has a long history of advocacy, having had input to many water policies through submissions and public meetings.

Mr Hall said in recent years, there had been a range of legislation and frameworks that intersected with water rights in Western Australia and nationally.

He said these included binding and non-binding international agreements with the Federal government, national agreements and legislation, State legislation and local government powers.

"These cover water, native title and heritage protection, among other issues," Mr Hall said.

"Local government can also significantly influence private property rights in water through planning, regulations and infrastructure positions.

"Some examples are climate adaptation strategies, local biodiversity strategies and reconciliation strategies.

"The Aboriginal Heritage Protection Act is particularly significant for water implications."

Mr Hall said the future should involve local ownership and management of water resources, with minimal threats to private property rights in water.

He said such threats to private property rights in water included the complexity of organisations, complacency, new environmental and Indigenous stakeholder interests, government regulations and bureaucracy, co-design rights, lack of government consultation and an emergence of a fourth tier of governance - Indigenous organisations.

"These factors may lead to inefficient and restrictive regulatory processes," Mr Hall said.

"It is a good idea for real estate agents to include all interested parties in water issues at the start of property negotiations.

"Stop being complacent about water and stop taking water for granted.

"Water is the most fundamental resource and it is best if advocacy groups collaborate and co-ordinate their efforts."

Western Australian Water Users Coalition executive officer Doug Hall said there were many policy issues that rural real estate agents needed to be aware of. Picture by Mel Williams.
