urn:contentItem:6GDB-85H3-RRPR-Y2JY-00000-00Canberra needs a climate plan: chair2025-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisSunday5Canberra needs a climate plan: chairJasper Lindell

'These things may not happen and yet we need to build for the possibility of risks.'

Canberra should prepare for days with temperatures soaring to 55 degrees and seize opportunities to invest in climate action that improves the health of the capital's residents, the new chair of the ACT Climate Change Council says.

Arnagretta Hunter, a cardiologist, said she thought the city needed to plan for temperature ranges from minus 15 to 55 degrees.

"These are built environment challenges we've not seen before, and this really asks us to think about where we work, how we work, how we look after each other, and the way in which we allocate our resources," Dr Hunter told budget estimates on Friday.

"It's a challenge around evaluation as well, because these things may not happen, and yet we need to build for the possibility of risks which we don't understand because we haven't seen them in the past.

"It's a complex area, but it's also one of the tremendous opportunities."

Dr Hunter said there needed to be an explicit acknowledgement of the need for imagination in climate adaptation work, to begin to "think about the sorts of things that haven't happened before and that might happen".

Dr Hunter, who served on the Climate Change Council since 2022 and was made chair last month, said investments in climate change mitigation could be readily justified on the grounds that those efforts actually protected and preserved human health.

"In a domestic home environment, particularly for those with less economic privilege, where we've got the opportunity to take gas out of the home environment for people who can't otherwise afford it, we actually can improve their health and wellbeing," she said.

"Isn't that a remarkable win-win?"

Meanwhile, the ACT Greens said work on climate change and environmental protection has "ground to a halt" since their members left cabinet after the October 2024 election and criticised the government for not lifting funding for environment groups.

Climate Change and Environment Minister Suzanne Orr, on Friday, was unable to say before the budget estimates committee precisely when a new territory climate change strategy would be completed.

The minister said the new strategy was being developed through cabinet processes with a plan to begin public consultation by year's end.

urn:contentItem:6GFD-M1C3-RRPD-7004-00000-00FED:More 'infrastructure, not advisers' key to Pacific aid2025-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisFED:More 'infrastructure, not advisers' key to Pacific aidPERTH Aug 8

  Spending more aid dollars on infrastructure in the Pacific and less on advisors would help Australia better compete with China for influence in the region, a think tank says.
   A "modest" reduction in advisers could fund almost half a billion dollars per year in desperately needed regional climate change adaptation investment, independent international policy think tank The Lowy Institute says.


   "Australia should be spending a lot more of its foreign aid to the Pacific on hard infrastructure investments related to helping the region become much more resilient to climate change," the institute's Indo-Pacific Development Centre director Roland Rajah told AAP.
   Pacific Island countries are among the most climate-vulnerable in the world and need to improve their physical infrastructure to cope with changing weather patterns and their impacts.
   This includes coastal protection projects to prevent flooding in urban centres and increasing the durability and resilience of general infrastructure, such as roads and drainage systems.
   Ports also need bolstering to cope with rising sea levels, and public buildings need to be more resilient to cyclones. Maintenance costs are also expected to rise with increased wear and tear.
   Australia spends about $2 billion per year in the Pacific and has signed deals for $2 billion in infrastructure funding.
   However, it only translates to about $80 million being spent on infrastructure projects each year, Mr Rajah said - well below the $2.3 billion the International Monetary Fund estimates the Pacific Island nations need to spend annually on climate adaptation.
   Australia's infrastructure investment facility for the Pacific is also almost out of funds.
   "If we just do what we've done and stop, then that's not really going to be very much," Mr Rajah said.
   "There needs to be some kind of top-up, and the obvious solution would just be to have a bigger aid program, but the politics around that just don't seem that favourable."
   The solution could be to cut the amount Australia spends on technical advice for Pacific Island nations to promote economic and governance reform, which is estimated to be about $700 million annually.
   "It's a very worthy goal, but ... that's a bit overkill, and we could usefully be repositioning that towards spending more on climate infrastructure," Mr Rajah said.
   More visible and tangible support for the Pacific's most pressing concern would also help Australia better compete with China for geo-strategic influence in the region.
   "We're completely outspending China in terms of foreign aid ... China's giving a few hundred million dollars a year, but we don't get much bang for our buck," Mr Rajah said.
   "Part of the reason is that China does much more tangible things like infrastructure, and we focus on these other things like governance.
   "Making the shift is smart development and smart diplomacy."

urn:contentItem:6GDP-5TR3-S8WP-M4G4-00000-00July 31, 2025: University of Technology Sydney: Research hub goes with the grain for AI adoption2025-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 31, 2025: University of Technology Sydney: Research hub goes with the grain for AI adoption

A new $11.7 million research hub will explore how the Australian grain industry can better use responsible artificial intelligence to be more productive and sustainable.

The Australian Research Council (ARC) Industrial Transformation Research Hub in Responsible AI for a Sustainable Grain Industry will develop cutting-edge artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to reduce fertiliser and diesel use, lower carbon emissions, and improve climate adaptation.

Led by Distinguished Professor Jie Lu, the research hub is a collaboration between experts from three Australian universities (UTS, University of Adelaide, Murdoch University), state government agencies, and 10 companies and industry organisations.

The hub has received $5 million from the ARC over the next five years, on top of $6.7 million from partner organisations.

"Australia has been at the forefront in using AI-driven new technology to drive the productivity and sustainability of agricultural industries including grains," said the new ARC research hub's director, Distinguished Professor Jie Lu.

"From sowing to distribution, AI is already providing insights and solutions for smarter and more sustainable grain-growing practices. However, further adoption of the technology will rely on developing responsible AI tools that are trusted by grain growers to be explainable and safe."

urn:contentItem:6G6Y-FJK3-RTB6-51PD-00000-00July 07, 2025: University of East Anglia Study Urges Immediate Measures to Combat River Delta Changes2025-07-08T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T20:55:34ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 07, 2025: University of East Anglia Study Urges Immediate Measures to Combat River Delta Changes

A recent study has identified the key drivers behind changes affecting river deltas globally, emphasizing the urgent necessity for action through climate adaptation and policy reform. Deltas, characterized as low-lying areas formed by the confluence of rivers and larger bodies of water like oceans, lakes, or other rivers, face significant threats from climate change. Major deltas, including the Rhine, Mekong, Ganges-Brahmaputra-Meghna, and Nile, are increasingly vulnerable to rising sea levels and more frequent extreme weather phenomena. Given that around 500 million people reside within or adjacent to delta systems, this issue requires immediate attention. An international team of scientists has established a new framework that outlines the ten main drivers of change affecting deltas worldwide, which encompass climate change, sea level rise, deforestation, intensive agriculture, urbanization, water impoundments, land subsidence, groundwater extraction, flood defenses, and resource mining. Many of these local, human-induced factors exhibit measurable impacts within a short timeframe. The framework provides a clear basis for prioritizing prompt, localized actions and enhances understanding of the complex systems influencing these dynamic environments. The findings are published today in Nature Climate Change, featuring researchers from the Universities of East Anglia, Southampton, and Oxford in the UK, alongside Deltares, TU Delft, Wageningen University, and Utrecht University in the Netherlands.

The outcomes of a new study on the extent of future flooding caused by climate change along the Clyde Estuary could help coastal cities around the world better defend themselves against rising tides and extreme weather. Sophisticated computer modelling of the Clyde by researchers at the University of Glasgow suggests that urban planners will need to adopt a 'right size, right place' approach to tidal flood management in the years to come.

June 18: University of Glasgow: UK screen leaders call for renewed focus on women's equality with launch of new guide

An evidence-based guide that will support women in film and television was launched at an event at the University of Glasgow.

The Deeds Not Words Policy Design Guide provides advice on designing and reviewing policies, interventions and action plans.

Sara Putt, Talent Agent and BAFTA Chair, is one of ten screen industry leaders who drafted and tested the Deeds Not Words Guide.

She said: "With others I am calling for a renewed focus on women's equality in the film and TV industries. Even with some significant gains and enormous effort, overall progress is slow. Now, the global economic and political environment is putting fragile progress in jeopardy. Concerted action on women's equity is needed now as much as it ever was."

The Deeds Not Words Guide is based on three years of international research co-led by Professor Doris Ruth Eikhof of the University of Glasgow, and CEO/Creative Director of the not-for-profit company Design Otherwise.

Five UofG academics have been awarded prestigious European Research Council (ERC) Advanced Grants - the most that the University has ever been awarded in one round.

Professor Steve Brewster (College of Science and Engineering); Professor Adam Carter (College of Arts and Humanities); Professor Ruth Dukes and Professor Fergus McNeill (College of Social Sciences); and Professor Simon Hanslmayr (College of Medical, Veterinary and Life Sciences), were all successful in the 2024 round of the competition, which is one of the most competitive funding schemes in the EU.

The Screen Carbon Test (SCT) - described by its creators as "food labelling for storylines" - uses a clear, traffic-light rating system to help audiences and industry professionals assess how effectively films and TV shows acknowledge CO₂ pollution and climate change, explore its causes and impacts and propose meaningful solutions.

June 20: University of Glasgow: Grand opening for spin-out's Pound12m 'Chemifarm' hailed as 'hugely significant milestone'

Deep-tech pioneer Chemify - the University of Glasgow's Spin-out of the Year 2024 - has performed the grand opening of its first Chemifarm - a new Pound12m production facility in Maryhill.

Professor Sir Anton Muscatelli, Principal and Vice-Chancellor of the University, said the occasion marked "a hugely significant milestone" in the University's strategy to translate cutting-edge research into commercial entities that can scale up to create jobs and economic impact for the city and region.

Founded in 2022, Chemify grew from Professor Lee Cronin's research in digital chemistry at the University and is fusing chemistry, robotics, computation and AI to digitise molecule creation.

The 21,500-ft square site at Oakbank Industrial Estate, off Garscube Road, unites Chemify's AI-driven molecular-design engine with industrial-scale robotic synthesis, compressing the journey from concept to compound and accelerating the discovery of small-molecule medicines and next-generation materials for partners tackling society's toughest challenges.

June 20: University of Glasgow: Turn on, tune in, crop out: 20 device uses ultrasound to produce fertiliser

A Pound20 device which makes fertiliser by treating water with ultrasound could transform agricultural supply chains in remote areas, its inventors say. Chemists and engineers from the University of Glasgow have found a way to produce molecules of nitrate - an important nutrient for plant growth - using just sound waves, water and air. They say their prototype process could be scaled up to enable individual farmers to make their own fertilisers on demand in the future. That, in turn, could reduce the carbon footprint of the agriculture sector, which currently relies on complex, expensive, and fossil-fuel driven factories for large-scale production of fertilisers like ammonia. The Haber-Bosch process, which drives most industrial ammonia production, creates around 2% of the world's annual carbon emissions.

June 09: University of Glasgow: Study reveals lasting mental health impacts of domestic violence

A groundbreaking study has found that women who experienced physical abuse in the context of domestic violence are more likely to suffer from long-term mental health challenges, even decades after the abuse has ended.

Approximately 30% of women worldwide will experience intimate partner violence - commonly referred to as domestic violence - in their lifetime. Often this will involve physical abuse, including risk of traumatic brain injury. Nevertheless, despite the prevalence of domestic violence and associated brain injuries, there has been little research into its potential long-lasting effects on brain health.

Image of a brain scan

To address this, The Drake IPV Study, led by the Professor Willie Stewart, Honorary Professor at the University of Glasgow, explored the mental health consequences associated with domestic violence and traumatic brain injury. The results are published in BMJ Mental Health.

Working with data from the multi-centre PREVENT Dementia Study, the researchers found that 14% of 632 study participants, who were aged 40-59 years-old at recruitment, reported a history of domestic violence with physical abuse. Compared with unexposed participants, a history of domestic violence was associated with higher traumatic brain injury exposure, alongside higher lifetime and ongoing diagnoses of mental health disorders, such as depression, anxiety, sleep disorders and PTSD.

Notably, the risk of ongoing mid-life mental health disorders remained despite the exposure to domestic violence having ceased, on average, 27 years before assessment.

Thomas McLean

Ellyane Wall has been endorsed by the Northern Territory Greens as part of her bid to run as a councillor for the City of Darwin's Chan Ward.

It marks the first public endorsement from any political party in the City of Darwin thus far in the 2025 election campaign.

In a statement, the NT Greens said Ms Wall was "passionate about climate action, accessibility and inclusion, participatory democracy, and youth representation".

Ms Wall volunteers with Rapid Creek Landcare and Birdlife NT, and she works as a roller-skating coach.

Chan Ward comprises the suburbs of Coconut Grove, East Point, Fannie Bay, Jingili, Ludmilla, Millner, Nightcliff and Rapid Creek.

Current councillor Morgan Rickard, who represents Chan Ward, was backed by the NT Greens in the 2021 local government elections, which he won in.

More recently, NT Greens candidate Kat McNamara narrowly won the electorate of Nightcliff in the 2024 NT Election.

Ms Wall said in a statement that Darwin was "my favourite place on Earth".

"I'm running for council because I want to make sure that my generation feels that they can build their futures here," she said.

"I love our community, our town, and our unique way of life. Serving on Council is an opportunity for me to give back to the community that has so fundamentally shaped who I am today.

"Council is so much more than rates, roads and rubbish. Our councils make decisions that impact everyone's experience of our community for years to come.

"I will be a strong voice for young people in our city, who are currently so under represented on council.

"As a councillor I would push for Darwin to become a leader in climate adaptation and sustainability. Our city has so much potential in this space - we just need the ambition to make it happen.

"I want to see our council investing in public spaces that are accessible, green and safe. These are essential for a thriving, cohesive and inclusive community.

"I will advocate for investment in spaces and programs to engage at-risk young people and people with a disability. Darwin should be a city that enables everyone to feel that they belong here."
